PARAGRAPH.STRING: (ancient Danuvius, ancient Greek Ἴστρος Istros) is the longest river of the European Union and Europe's second-longest (after the Volga).
originates in the Black Forest in Germany as two smaller rivers--the Brigach and the Breg--which join at Donaueschingen, and it is from here that

is known as the Danube, flowing generally eastwards for a distance of some 2850 km (1771 miles), passing through several Central and Eastern European capitals, before emptying into the Black Sea via the Danube Delta in Romania.
has been an important international waterway for centuries, as
remains today. Known to history as one of the long-standing frontiers of the Roman Empire,

forms a part of the borders of--ten countries: Germany, Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Bulgaria, Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine; in addition, the drainage basin includes parts of ten more countries: Italy, Poland, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Republic of Macedonia, Moldova, and Albania.

([German: Donau], [Slovak: Dunaj], [Albanian: Danubi], [Polish: Dunaj], [Hungarian: Duna], [Croatian: Dunav], Serbian: Дунав / Dunav], [Bulgarian: Дунав] (Dunav), Romanian: [Romanian: Dunăre], [Ukrainian: Дунай] (Dunay), [Italian: Danubio], [Latin: Danuvius], modern Greek: Δούναβης, [Turkish: Tuna], Slovene: Donava, local Yiddish: Duner - [] and Tine - []) are all ultimately derived from the Proto-Indo-European *'dānu, meaning "river" or "stream". Still nowadays don in Ossetic language means both "water" and "river". Other major European river names with this Indo-European root for "stream" include the Donets, Dnieper, Dniester, the Don River, Russia and the River Don, England.
